I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Hunan Technical and Vocational Education and 
Training (TVET) Demonstration Project.1 
 
The  project  seeks  to  improve  the  quality  and  relevance  of  formal  TVET  in  Hunan 
2. 
province.  Quality 
include  developing  competency-based  standards  and 
curriculum,  training  vocational  instructors,  and  strengthening  TVET  management  capacity  in 
Hunan’s TVET institutions to support inclusive and environmentally sustainable development. A 
key  project  focus  is  on  strengthening  industry  participation  in  TVET  and  ensuring  greater 
alignment between TVET and labor market needs.2   
 

improvements 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
The PRC is one of the fastest growing economies, with an average annual growth rate of 
over 9.0% since the 1980s. The government’s 12th Five-Year Plan, 2011–2015, targets annual 
gross domestic product (GDP) growth of 7.5%. Despite impressive growth, the PRC is facing a 
number of urgent development challenges. The government’s key priorities include restructuring 
the  economy  from  production  and  export  to  consumption-oriented  growth,  from  low  to  higher 
value-added industries, and supporting rapid urbanization and environmentally sustainable and 
socially  inclusive  development—all  of  which  require  significant  investments  in  human  capital. 
Strengthening  human  resources  through the  development  of  TVET  is  one  of  the  key  priorities 
under the 12th Five-Year Plan. 
 
4. 
The  PRC  is  experiencing  skill  and  labor  shortages.  National  labor  market  data  from 
91 cities  in  2012  showed  that  demand  exceeded  supply  in  almost  all  technical  and  skilled 
categories.  The  PRC’s  comparative  advantage  in  low-skilled  labor-intensive  production  is 
expected  to  decline,  with the  economy  shifting  to more  skill-intensive  products  and  production 
technologies.  The  Government  of  the  PRC  is  increasingly  emphasizing  the  value  of  highly 
skilled  human  capital.  In  2010,  the  central  government  identified  TVET  as  the  key  target  for 
educational  expansion  to  develop  a  skilled  work  force,  and  approved  the  National  Long-Term 
Strategy  on  Education,  2010–2020.  The  education  plan  sets  up  goals  and  reforms  to  better 
align the education system with the demands of economic and social development. 
 
5. 
Hunan is a province with a population of 70 million, located in the south central part of 
the  PRC.  The  GDP  per  capita  of  Hunan  in  2011  was  $4,742,  below  the  national  average  of 
$5,583. In 2011, 9.08 million people, or 15.9% of the rural registered population in Hunan lived 
below the national poverty line, higher than the national average of 13.4%.3  
 
6. 
The  structure  of  Hunan’s  economy  is  undergoing  fundamental  transformation.  The 
Government of the PRC’s policy of geographical rebalancing of economic growth toward inland 
provinces has led to Hunan’s emergence as an important industrial base, requiring a large and 
multi-skilled  work

the  manufacturing  and  services  sectors  in  Hunan  has  been  higher  than  the  national  average, 
particularly  for  the  manufacturing  sector,  which  contributed  56.0%  to  Hunan’s  GDP  in  2010. 
Demand for skilled workers in Hunan exceeded supply in 2011, with manufacturing having the 
highest  demand.  Hunan  ranks  19th  in  the  PRC  in  terms  of  educational  attainment,  with  an 
average  level  of  educational  attainment  of  9.1  years.  The  urbanization  level  of  Hunan  was 
45.0%  in  2011,  and  is  forecast  to  grow  to  66.0%  by  2030.  Increased  industrialization  and 
urbanization, and the subsequent transformation of livelihood bases, will require skilled workers. 
 
7. 
Since 2007, Hunan provincial government (HPG) has been actively pursuing reforms in 
the  TVET  sector.  Investment  in  TVET  development  has  played  an  important  role  in  helping 
disadvantaged  people gain  new  skills  and enjoy  the growth  benefits,  as over  80%  of  students 
enrolled in Hunan’s TVET institutions are from rural areas or low-income urban families. Despite 
impressive  progress,  TVET  development  in  Hunan  faces  a  number  of  challenges,  including 
(i) limited  industry  involvement,  (ii)  lack  of  accurate  and  consistently  sourced  labor  market 
information, (iii) outdated curriculum and teaching and learning materials, (iv) need to upgrade 
instructional  skills  and  workplace  experience  of  vocational  instructors,  (v)  inadequate  TVET 
institution  management  capacity  to  strengthen  linkages  between  schools  and  industry,  and 
(vi) lack of and/or  obsolete  equipment to  simulate  a  workplace for  practical  demonstration  and 
application.  
 
8. 
Greater involvement of enterprises in advising and directing the TVET system is critical 
to increase TVET’s responsiveness to labor  market  needs.  HPG  established  industry  advisory 
groups (IAGs) as a way to foster industry involvement in TVET, but the capacity of the IAGs to 
engage with industry needs to be strengthened. While demand for workers is strong in Hunan 
and  placement  rates  for  graduates  are  high  (over  80%  in  many  TVET  institutions),  TVET 
institutions are faced with the challenge of updating their programs to meet the demands of new 
industries, and upgrading older industries.  
 
9. 
To address these challenges, the project will provide targeted support to 13 public TVET 
institutions  in  Hunan  to  strengthen  the  capability  to  deliver  demand-driven  quality  programs 
related to priority industries. The project will  build the capacity of IAGs and foster partnerships 
between 13 project TVET institutions and employers to jointly develop the skills needed  in the 
workplace,  and  prepare  graduates  who  are  able  to  adjust  to  changing  demands  in  the  labor 
market quickly; modernize the curriculum by developing competency-based curriculum (CBC) in 
priority  areas;  upgrade  the  instructional  capacity  of  vocational  instructors  and  build  TVET 
management  capacity;  strengthen  market-oriented  program  planning  through  improved  labor 
market  information  system  (LMIS);  and  upgrade  equipment  and  facilities  in  selected  TVET 
institutions.  
 
Strategic  fit.  The  project  is  the  first  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)-financed  lending 
10. 
project  for  TVET  in  the  PRC  and  is  envisaged  to  play  a  demonstration  role  for  TVET 
development  in  the  country.  Because  lack  of  worker  skills  and  education  are  viewed  as  a 
constraint  to  the  PRC’s  inclusive  growth,  ADB  involvement  in  the  TVET  sector  is  strongly 
justified.  The  project  supports  ADB’s  education  policy  and  education  sector  strategies  and 
Strategy  2020. 4  It  aligns  with  ADB’s  PRC  country  partnership  strategy,  2011–2015 5  and 
supports  the  PRC’s  12th  Five-Year  Plan,  which  prioritizes  developing  high-quality  human

11.  
Incorporation  of  the  lessons  learned.  Lessons  from  activities  in  skills  training 
supported  by  ADB  and  the  World  Bank  were  incorporated  into  the  project  design.  Lessons 
include  (i)  actively  involving  representatives  of  industries  and  IAGs  in  identifying  occupational 
areas that are in demand, developing competencies for market-demanded occupational areas, 
and working with the project TVET institutions to develop modular, CBC and learning materials; 
(ii)  conducting  tracer  studies  of  the  trainees,  and  strengthening  the  capacity  of  the  relevant 
government  agencies  and  the  TVET  institutions  to  analyze  labor  market  demand;  and  (iii) 
establishing a project benefit monitoring and evaluation system. 
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

12. 
The  impact  of  the  proposed  project  will  be  that  adequate  skilled  human  resources  are 
available  to  contribute  to  inclusive  growth  and  social  development  in  Hunan  province.  The 
outcome will be strengthened capacity of the formal TVET system to meet labor market needs. 
 
C. 

Outputs 

13.   Output  1:  Improved  quality  and  relevance  of  the  technical  and  vocational 
education  and  training  system.  Under  this  output,  the  project  will  provide  support  to 
(i) develop  competency-based  standards  and  revise  selected  training  programs  using  CBC  in 
priority  sectors;6 (ii)  develop  teaching  and  learning  materials  to  support  CBC;  (iii)  improving 
access of the TVET institutions in poor and remote areas to high-quality online TVET courses, 
in  order  to  maximize  resource  sharing  among  TVET  institutions;  (iv)  upgrade  vocational 
instructor  skills  through  industry  placements  and  in-service  training  programs;  (v)  strengthen 
TVET management capacity; and (vi) improve learning environments through upgraded training 
equipment  such  as  specialist  workshops, 
laboratories,  and  multimedia  and  computer

14.   Output  2:  Upgraded  facilities  and  learning  environments.  The  project  will  upgrade 
facilities  including  construction  of  teaching,  learning,  and  practice  buildings  within  existing 
campuses of five TVET institutions. These five TVET institutions were selected based on their 
need  for  civil  works  in  accordance  with  their  respective  campus  development  plans,  and  the 
suitability  of  these  works  for  ADB  funding.  The  project  will  support  greening  of  the  TVET 
campuses  by  designing,  constructing,  and maintaining  buildings that  reduce  energy  and  water 
use. The  project  will  develop  guidelines for  sustainable practices on TVET campuses  such  as 
reducing, reusing, and recycling resources and support selected TVET institutions in setting up 
environmental management systems.

15.   Output  3:  Strengthened 
education  and  training.  Under  this  output,  the  project  will  provide  support  to  (i)  build  the 
capacity  of  the  IAGs  to  forge  stronger  partnerships  between  TVET  institutions  and  local 
enterprises,  develop  competency  standards,  and  identify  labor  market  needs;  (ii)  strengthen 
management  committees  at  the  project  TVET  institutions  to  include  industry  participation;  (iii) 
establish formal partnership agreements between the project TVET institutions and enterprises 
and  IAGs;  (iv) assess  the  quality  and  relevance  of  training  programs  by  measuring  graduate 
employment  and  employability  through  improved  tracer  studies;  (v)  establish  a  pilot  LMIS 
involving  two  priority  industries  as  a  starting  point  to  encourage  market-oriented  program 
planning; (vi) establish a provincial level interagency LMIS coordination committee, as a policy 
discussion  vehicle  to  discuss  data  sharing  and  development  of  the  LMIS;  (vii)  strengthen  the 
capacity  of  Hunan  Education  Department  (HED)  staff  to  collect  and  analyze  labor  market 
information;  (viii) conduct  policy  research  studies  to  develop  strategies  for  strengthening 
enterprise–school  partnerships  and  undertake  skills  mapping  to  identify  the  skills  needed  for 
environmentally  sustainable  development;  and  (ix) develop  institutional  partnerships  between 
selected  project  TVET  institutions  and  overseas  vocational  colleges  to  strengthen  knowledge 
sharing and capacity building. 
 
16. 
Output  4:  Project  management  support  established.  Under  this  output,  the  project 
will  (i)  provide  training  and  project  implementation  support;  (ii)  improve  monitoring  and 
evaluation  to  capture  lessons  from  project  activities  under  components  1,  2,  and  3;  and 
(iii) regularly disseminate the experiences gained, including a project website aimed  at sharing 
key  information  about  the  project.  The  project  will  carry  out  baseline,  tracer,  and  evaluation 
studies;  and  organize  workshops  to  exchange  school–industry  collaboration  and  curriculum 
development case studies and lessons learned.

The  government  has  requested  a  loan  of  $50  million  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
resources to help finance the project. The loan will have a 26-year term, including a grace period 
of  5  years,  an  annual  interest  rate  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank 
offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility,7 a commitment charge of 0.15%  per year, and such 
other  terms  and conditions  set  forth  in  the  draft  loan  and  project  agreement. The  government 
will finance the remaining amount of $55.84 million of project cost including contingencies. The 
government has provided ADB with (i) the reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-
based  lending  facility  based  on  these  terms  and  conditions,  and  (ii) an  undertaking  that  these 
choices  were  its  own  independent  decision  and  not  made  in  reliance  on  any  communication  or 
advice from ADB. The financing  plan  is  in Table  2  and  is  detailed  in  the  project  administration 
manual (PAM).8

 III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

21. 
The  project  will  directly  benefit  over  86,000 full-time  students  in  certificate and  diploma 
courses who will access quality study programs closely aligned to the needs of employers over 
5  years  of  the  project  duration.  Employers  will  benefit  from  improvements  in  the  quality  and 
relevance  of  TVET  as  improved  skill  levels  are  directly  linked  to  improving  workplace 
productivity,  product  quality,  and  service  standards.  By  improving  the  quality  and relevance of 
study programs, community and industry confidence in the TVET system to provide a pathway 
to meaningful employment will increase. The instructor development program will enable up to 
2,000  instructors  to  be  up-skilled  through  improved  in-service  teacher  training.  TVET 
management  capacity  building  will  enable  up  to  500  TVET  managers  to  strengthen  their 
management skills through improved management training programs. 
 
A. 

Economic and Financial 

22. 
Economic benefits. The economic benefits from the project will be derived mainly from 
the  incremental  productivity  gains  resulting  from  improved  quality  and  efficiency  of  training, 
expressed  in  terms  of  the  incremental  income  of  the  graduates.  The  direct  economic  benefits 
from  the  project  will  flow  from  the  increased  numbers  of  TVET  graduates  who  will  find  direct 
employment.  Based  on  conservative  assumptions,  such  targeted  skills  development  can 
increase monthly wages by CNY76. Estimating these benefits over 25 years, based on the total 
project  cost  of  $105.84  million,  yields  an  economic  internal  rate  of  return  of  16.9%.  Individual 
economic  internal  rates  of  return  have  been  computed  for  each  TVET  institution  and  yield 
satisfactory results. These are documented in the economic analysis.9 Other indirect benefits of 
the project, which will most likely accrue to society at large and not just the direct beneficiaries 
of the project, are (i) improvements in the provision of quality skills at selected TVET institutions 
will also benefit non-project TVET institutions and thereby improve the quality and relevance of 
the sector to the needs of industry, and (ii) enhanced responsiveness of TVET will improve the 
relevance of skills and employment outcomes of graduates beyond project completion.  
 
23. 
Financial sustainability. A financial sustainability analysis was undertaken during project 
preparation,  based  on fiscal  impact.  The  project  should  be  financially  sustainable  as  the  bulk  of 
expenditures  do  not  carry  on  beyond  the  end  of  the  project.  Recurrent  expenditures  such  as 
equipment maintenance cost can be absorbed by additional revenues from government funding, 
tuition fees,  and tailored  training for  enterprises.  The financial  analysis  shows  that  during fiscal 
years 2009–2011, total recurrent expenditure for TVET has almost doubled from CNY2.7 billion 
to  CNY4.7  billion,  indicating  the  relative  importance  given  to  increasing  skills  improvement  in 
Hunan.10 The project will increase the labor market relevance of the TVET system, and this will 
improve the sustainability of the TVET sector by making it better serve Hunan’s socioeconomic 
development  needs.  Efficiency  gains  in  the  13  project  TVET  institutions  will  also  be  realized

C. 

Poverty and Social 

 

The  project  contributes  to  the  central  and  provincial  government’s  poverty  alleviation 
25. 
strategies of enhancing the employability and skills of the labor force. In Hunan Province, over 
80%  of  TVET  students  are  from  rural  and  low-income  backgrounds.  The  project  will  support 
Hunan’s  distance  education  platform,  which  can  reach  thousands  of  adult  learners  in  Hunan 
every  year  through  short-term  distance  learning  courses  to  improve  the  skills  of  farmers  and 
rural  migrants.  This  will  help  ensure  socially  inclusive  TVET  and  serve  as  a  model  for  other 
provinces  seeking  to  increase  the  impact  and  scope  of  their  TVET  programs.  The  project  will 
make selected online TVET courses available on Hunan’s TVET portal for vocational schools in 
remote, poor areas, thus providing benefits to students from rural areas in non-project schools.  
 
26. 
Gender  and  development.  The  project  is  categorized  effective  gender  mainstreaming 
and  includes  a  social  and  gender  action  plan  (SGAP)  to  facilitate  and  promote  the  increased 
participation  and  employment  of  female  students  in  priority  industries.  Gender  analysis  of 
students  and  staff  at  the  project  TVET  institutions  revealed  a  broad gender  balance  in  overall 
student and teaching numbers, but a significant under-representation of women in management 
level  jobs  in  the  TVET  institutions  and  a  gender  imbalanced  enrolment  depending  on  fields  of 
study. The key gender issues addressed by the project include (i) limited access of females to 
nontraditional  quality  skill  development  programs,  (ii)  limited  access  to  management  training 
and  teacher  training  among  female  instructors,  (iii)  gender  stereotypes  in  the  curriculum,  and 
(iv) lack of knowledge related to the range of study programs and career prospects for females 
in  male  dominant  skill  areas.  The  SGAP  includes  the  following  targets  and  gender-responsive 
design  features:  (i)  at  least  40%  of  instructors  trained  will  be  female,  (ii)  at  least  40%  of 
managers  trained  will  be  female,  (iii)  a  social  marketing  campaign  will  be  implemented  to 
promote female participation in nontraditional trades in priority sectors, (iv) gender indicators will 
be  developed  in  the  pilot  LMIS,  and  (v)  gender  monitoring  and  evaluation  indicators  will  be 
integrated in the overall design and monitoring framework to track  SGAP implementation. The

mechanism and handle any dispute arising from noncompliance with the EMP.  
 
28. 
Resettlement.  The  involuntary  resettlement  category  is  C.  The  project  activities  will 
neither  require  land  acquisition  nor  resettlement.  Resettlement  due  diligence  was  conducted, 
which confirmed that there are no legacy issues from the time the campuses were established.  
 
29. 
Indigenous  people.  The  indigenous  peoples’  category  is  C.  No  project  activities  will 
adversely affect indigenous people. The poverty and social assessment determined that ethnic 
minority  students  are  well  integrated  into  all  the  project  TVET  institutions.  Increased  quality  of 
TVET as a result of the project will benefit all students, including ethnic minorities.
